titleInfo.title: Effects of a Prolonged Bout of Running on Hepcidin and Iron Homeostasis

name.namePart: College of Health and Human Sciences
Department of Nutrition and Integrative Physiology

mods:mods.abstract: Declines in iron status are frequently reported in those who regularly engage in strenuous physical activity. A proposed reason is increases in the iron regulatory hormone hepcidin, which functions to inhibit dietary iron absorption and can be induced by the inflammatory cytokine interleukin-6. Prolonged physical activity results in an inflammatory response, and circulating hepcidin is consistently shown to increase with physical activity >60 min in duration, typically peaking 3-6 h following completion of exercise. Thus, physically active individuals may experience declines in iron status overtime due to reduced dietary iron absorption. However, current evidence using stable iron isotopes is conflicting on whether dietary iron absorption decreases in the post-exercise state. Furthermore, while inflammatory signaling of hepcidin is the leading hypothesis for post-exercise increases in hepcidin, evidence suggests that gluconeogenic signals in response to low energy availability may also contribute. In Chapter 1, the literature is reviewed on hepcidin's regulation of systemic iron homeostasis and its proposed role in the declines in iron status with physical activity, with a particular emphasis on the mechanisms that induce hepcidin. Chapter 2 details a published study that sought to determine the effects of a prolonged bout of running on hepcidin and dietary iron absorption, compared to rest, in trained collegiate cross country runners. Following the run, circulating hepcidin increased and dietary iron absorption decreased compared to the rest condition, however, evidence for inflammatory signaling of hepcidin was not convincing. These findings provided rationale for the study in Chapter 3, which aimed to investigate the contribution of REDD1, a known target of IL-6 and gluconeogenic hormone signals, on the responses of hepcidin and its regulators following prolonged treadmill running. Liver mRNA expression of hepcidin and its regulators were measured in REDD1 knockout and wildtype mice after rest or 1, 3, or 6 h recovery from 60 min treadmill running. Both treadmill running and REDD1 knockout increased expression of hepcidin, gluconeogenic regulators of hepcidin, and markers of gluconeogenesis. Moreover, hepcidin was correlated with gluconeogenic regulators of hepcidin and markers of gluconeogenesis, indicating a possible role of gluconeogenic signaling of hepcidin following prolonged physical activity. Findings presented in this dissertation indicate that post-exercise increases in hepcidin may lead to declines in iron status due to decreased dietary iron absorption following exercise. Second, post-exercise hepcidin may be influenced by gluconeogenic signaling in the post-exercise state, which potentially informs dietary strategies to mitigate the post-exercise hepcidin response and prevent declines in iron status with frequent physical activity.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Nutrition and Integrative Physiology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Nutrition Sciences.
endurance exercise, gluconeogenesis, hepcidin, iron deficiency, low energy availability, REDD1

Stephen R. Hennigar, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Bradley S. Gordon, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Claire E. Berryman, Ph.D., R.D, Committee Member; Robert C. Hickner, Committee Member; Michael J. Ormsbee, Committee Member; David W. Eccles, University Representative.
